title: Corona Extra logo blackletter
content:
I am working on a project that is using the Corona Extra labels as the theme.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20111219111314im_/http:/typophile.com/files/CoronaExtraLogo_4941.jpg)

I came up with something close to the C with plainblack wide font, but I really have a hard time looking through all my fonts without crashing my computer....I need a new one. It looks like 2 seperate fonts...one for the capital C in Corona and for the lowercase. Anyone know a font that is close to these?

I need to identify the lowercase, the C in Corona, and the E in extra.

Thanks in advance for your help!
author: Eyerish53

comments.content: The whole thing is almost certainly custom drawn, but it's a textura blackletter. You could try [LTC Goudy Text](http://web.archive.org/web/20111219111314/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/lanston/ltc-goudy-text) or [Old English Text](http://web.archive.org/web/20111219111314/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/agfa/old-english-text) to get decently close.
Another common one that is very close to most of it is called Wedding Text.

I think the lower case looks most like a Fraktur, because of the 'a', and [Fette Fraktur](http://web.archive.org/web/20111219111314/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/fette-fraktur/) seems pretty close. A simplified version of the caps of [Engraver's Old English](http://web.archive.org/web/20111219111314/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/bitstream/engravers-old-english/) might do for the initial letters.

- Mike Yanega

Here was [a thread about the tradition of blackletter with Mexican sign-painters](http://web.archive.org/web/20111219111314/http:/www.typophile.com/node/17496), with some interesting examples. A few I got in Ensenada are on page 2.
